lexicon_requests.reason: Infinitive construct with preposition - rare temporal construction in superscriptions, need syntactic patterns
Nominal form of adversary - semantic range and relationship to verbal root צרר
Participle 'rising against' - military/rebellion usage vs. general standing, especially for verbal irony with קוּמָה
Syntactic puzzle: 'to my soul' or 'about me'? Need prepositional usage patterns with נפש
Feminine suffix on 'deliverance' - need gender/suffix patterns and theological significance
Shield as divine epithet - military vs. theological usage, frequency as God-metaphor
Spatial preposition 'around/behind me' - precise locative meaning for encirclement theology
Critical syntactic puzzle: 'my glory' with possessive - when does glory belong TO psalmist vs. IS God?
Hiphil participle 'lifter' - causative sense and honor/shame cultural context
Verb 'sustain/support/uphold' in v. 6 - semantic range between physical support and providential sustenance
Escalation from רַבִּים to myriads - numerical terminology and hyperbolic usage
Verb 'set/place' in military context (v. 7) - why this verb for hostile positioning?
Perfect verb 'struck' - temporal ambiguity (prophetic perfect? past pattern?) and judicial vs. combat contexts
Cheek/jaw - judicial slap vs. combat violence, honor/shame implications, ANE legal contexts
Perfect 'broke' with teeth - metaphorical range (disarm biting? silence speech? both?)

concordance_requests.purpose: Track interrogative + רבב formula expressing numerical overwhelm
Negative deliverance claims - theological denials to compare with v. 3 taunt
Prepositional ב with divine name - 'through/in God' theological claims
Inclusio with v. 3 - 'to YHWH belongs deliverance' formula
Shield + spatial preposition - encircling protection imagery
Lifting head idiom - honor restoration vs. judicial execution contexts
Holy mountain formula - temple theology and divine presence geography
Sleep testimony formula - vulnerability and trust language
Divine warrior imperative - cultic formula for divine intervention
Striking enemies - combat vs. judicial violence patterns
Breaking teeth imagery - curse literature and combat metaphors
Individual-to-corporate shift - blessing on 'Your people' liturgical formulas

figurative_requests.reason: Rising/standing enemies - military uprising metaphor, rebellion imagery | Vehicle: rising | Related terms: rise, rises, stood, stand, stands, standing, arise, arises, arising
Shield imagery - divine protection metaphor, central divine epithet | Vehicle: shield | Related terms: shields, buckler, bucklers
Lifting head - honor restoration metaphor, embodied dignity | Vehicle: lift head | Related terms: raise head, lifted head, raised head, exalt head, exalted head
Sleep during siege - radical vulnerability as embodied trust metaphor | Vehicle: sleep | Related terms: sleeping, sleeps, slept, slumber, slumbers, slumbering

Encirclement/surrounding - siege warfare imagery, spatial threat | Vehicle: surround | Related terms: surrounding, surrounds, surrounded, encircle, encircles, encircled, encircling, compass, compassed
Striking cheek/jaw - judicial humiliation or combat violence, honor/shame imagery | Vehicle: strike cheek | Related terms: smite cheek, struck cheek, smitten cheek, hit jaw, struck jaw
Breaking teeth - disarmament metaphor, silencing mockery | Vehicle: break teeth | Related terms: broken teeth, shatter teeth, shattered teeth, smash teeth, smashed teeth, crush teeth, crushed teeth

commentary_requests.reason: Superscription linking to Absalom narrative - how commentators handle historical context and father-son betrayal tragedy
Opening lament with numerical crisis - traditional interpretation of מה רבו rhetorical question and escalating threat
Enemy taunt about divine deliverance - classical exegesis of לְנַפְשִׁי syntax and theological denial אין ישועה בא להים
Pivotal adversative with triple divine epithets - how commentators parse כְּבוֹדִי syntax (God = my glory vs. restores glory)
Past divine response testimony - traditional understanding of spatial theology puzzle (answering from holy mountain while fleeing)
Sleep during military crisis - commentators on radical trust embodiment and miraculous peace claim
Paradoxical numerical escalation at confidence peak - classical interpretation of fearlessness amid myriads
Violent petition with body imagery - how commentators handle perfect verb temporal ambiguity (prophetic? past pattern?) and striking cheek/breaking teeth metaphors
Climactic inclusio and person shift - traditional understanding of individual-to-corporate movement and liturgical adaptation

macro_questions: What is the theological and rhetorical significance of the fourfold repetition of רבב (many) in vv. 2-3, and does it connect to Ancient Near Eastern numerical symbolism or military contexts?

How does the body imagery progression (shield—head—face—teeth) function as a conceptual map of protection, honor, judgment, and disarmament? Are there Ugaritic or ANE parallels to this imagery sequence?
What is the spatial theology of 'holy mountain' (v. 5) when the superscription depicts David fleeing FROM Jerusalem? How do other Zion psalms handle God's presence beyond temple geography?

Are the perfect verb forms in v. 8 ('You struck... You broke') prophetic perfects (certain future), precative perfects (expressing wish), or recollection of past divine pattern? How does each reading affect the psalm's rhetoric?
What is the significance of sleep (v. 6) as a trust motif in the Psalter? How does Ps 3:6 relate to Ps 4:8, 127:2, and the broader biblical theology of rest?
What is the syntactic function of לו ('for him' or 'to him') in v. 3—are enemies speaking TO the psalmist (direct taunt) or ABOUT him (third-person mockery)? How does LXX interpret this?
How does 'breaking teeth' (v. 8) function in ANE warfare, curse, and legal contexts? Is this about physical combat, judicial disarmament, or silencing verbal opponents?
What is the relationship between v. 9's universal conclusion ('Your people') and the individual focus of vv. 2-8? Is this evidence of liturgical adaptation from personal to communal use?
How do the three Selah markers structure the psalm liturgically? Do they indicate congregational response, musical interlude, or contemplative pause?
What is the theological force of God as 'shield AROUND me' (בעדי, v. 4) versus God as shield more generally? Does this image respond specifically to enemies 'surrounding' (סביב, v. 7)?
How does the face-striking imagery (לחי, 'cheek/jaw,' v. 8) function as judicial humiliation versus combat violence? Compare to ancient legal texts and prophetic usage.
micro_questions: What is the syntactic function and theological implication of לְנַפְשִׁי in v. 3 - are enemies speaking TO the psalmist's soul (direct taunt) or ABOUT him (third-person mockery)? How does this affect the psychology of threat?

Why does v. 4 use כְּבוֹדִי ('my glory') with possessive suffix? Is this theological identification (God = my glory) or restoration claim (God restores my honor)? What is the syntactic relationship - apposition or predication?

How do the perfect verb forms in v. 8 (הִכִּיתָ 'You struck', שִׁבַּרְתָּ 'You broke') function temporally - are they prophetic perfects (certain future), precative perfects (wishes), or recollections of past divine pattern? How does each reading affect the psalm's rhetoric of confidence?

What is the significance of the geographical paradox between v. 1's superscription (David fleeing FROM Jerusalem) and v. 5's claim that God answers 'from His holy mountain'? Does this assert divine presence transcends temple geography, or is this proleptic anticipation of return?

Why does the numerical escalation from רַבִּים ('many', vv. 2-3) to רִבְבוֹת ('myriads', v. 7) occur precisely at the moment of greatest confidence? What rhetorical work does this paradoxical intensification perform?

How does the sleep testimony in v. 6 function rhetorically and theologically - is this hyperbolic rhetoric of trust, actual historical claim, or embodied metaphor that PERFORMS trust through vulnerable bodily state? How does sleep relate to holy war tradition?

What is the precise metaphorical import of 'breaking teeth' (שִׁנֵּי שִׁבַּרְתָּ, v. 8) - does this disarm physical threat (biting), silence verbal mockery (speech), or both? How do ANE curse texts and legal contexts illuminate this imagery?

Why do enemies use אֱלֹהִים (generic 'God', v. 3) while the psalmist predominantly uses יְהוָה (covenant name)? Does divine name choice signal theological positioning - abstract deity vs. relational covenant partner?

How does the spatial preposition בַּעֲדִי ('around me', v. 4) relate to the encirclement verb סָבִיב שָׁתוּ ('they set themselves around', v. 7)? Does God's protective encirclement directly answer enemy hostile encirclement?

What explains the dramatic person shift in v. 9 from first-person singular ('I/me/my') throughout vv. 2-8 to second-person reference to 'Your people'? Is this evidence of liturgical adaptation from personal lament to communal worship resource?

How does the body imagery progression (shield v. 4 → head lifted v. 4 → face struck/teeth broken v. 8) map conceptually onto protection → honor → judgment? Does this sequence reflect ANE honor/shame cultural logic?

What is the function of the verbal irony in קום root repetition - enemies קָמִים ('rising against', v. 2) versus imperative to God קוּמָה ('Rise!', v. 8)? Does this linguistic play argue that enemy aggression necessitates/invites divine counter-aggression?
